did.head: Descriptive Summary

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Local government records collection, Northampton County Court Records. The Library of Virginia, Richmond, Va. 23219.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These items came to the Library of Virginia in a transfer of court papers from Northampton County.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Northampton County probably was named for the English county, of which Obedience Robins, a prominent early resident of the Eastern Shore, was a native. The county, which originally included all of the peninsula south of Maryland and which was one of the eight shires established in 1634, was first called Accomac. The name was changed by legislative action in 1643.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Northampton County (Va.) Free Negro and Slave Records, 1723-1808. These records are comprised mostly of petitions pertaining to the free or slave status of several persons living in Northampton County between 1723 and 1758; and slave patrol accounts, 1804-1808. Included are petitions for freedom and petitions charging that free persons, some of whom are identified as Indian or mulatto, have been bound out or held illegally as slaves. The slave patrol accounts include the names of people appointed to slave patrols, when they served, and how much they were paid.

Also included are two letters documenting the importation of Quodindo Odenda, a slave, by W. Charles in 1744; a petition to bind out a free negro orphan, and Free Negro Delinquent Tax list identifying 62 free negroes owing taxes in 1804. Also included in the list is the name, in most cases, of the person from whom the individual was emancipated.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional Northampton County Free Negro and Slave Records can be found on microfilm at the Library of Virginia. Consult A Guide to Virginia County and City Records on Microfilm.
